contentrichtext.text: {{About|the Aztec underworld|the rapper|Doomtree|the wrestler|Mictlán (wrestler)}} '''Mictlan''' ({{IPA-nah|'mikt͡ɬaːn}}) was the [[underworld]] of [[Aztec mythology]]. Most people who died went to Mictlan, although other possibilities existed (see "Other Destinations," below).<ref name="Smith2009p207" /> Mictlan was located far to the north,{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} and consisted of nine distinct levels.<ref name="Smith2009p207" /> The journey from the first level to the ninth was difficult and took four years, but the dead were aided by the [[psychopomp]], [[Xolotl]]. The dead had to pass many challenges, such as crossing a mountain range where the mountains crashed into each other, a field with wind that blew flesh-scraping knives, and a river of blood with fearsome jaguars.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} Mictlan was ruled by a king, [[Mictlantecuhtli]] ("Lord of the Underworld")<ref name="Smith2009p206" /> and his wife, [[Mictecacihuatl]] ("Lady of the Underworld").<ref>Soustelle, Jacques (Patrick O'Brian, translator) (1961). ''Daily Life of the Aztecs on the Eve of the Spanish Conquest''. Stanford: Stanford University Press. p. 107.</ref> Other deities in Mictlan included [[Cihuacoatl (goddess)|Cihuacoatl]] (who commanded Mictlan spirits called [[Cihuateteo]]), [[Acolnahuacatl (deity)|Acolmiztli]], [[Chalmecacihuilt]], [[Chalmecatl]] and [[Acolnahuacatl (deity)|Acolnahuacatl]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} ==Other destinations== In addition to Mictlan, the dead could also go to a number of other destinations: *Warriors who died in battle and those who died as a sacrifice went east and accompanied the sun during the morning.<ref name="Smith2009p207" /> *Women who died in [[childbirth]] went to the west and accompanied the sun when it set in the evening.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Coe| first=Michael D. |title=Mexico: From the Olmecs to the Aztecs |year=1994| edition=4 |place=London |publisher=Thames and Hudson |page=183 }}</ref> *People who died of drowning — or from other causes that were seen as linked to the rain god [[Tlaloc]], such as certain diseases and lightning — went to a paradise called [[Tlalocan]].<ref name="Smith2009p207" /> ==References== {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="Smith2009p206">Smith, M.
